Gentlemen?
I thought you would get some inspiration out of this exchange of corres¬
pondence between Dick Rider and various staff members of Th© Cooper Union* It is
funny what a little thing can do.
This will be the shortest Policy Letter on record. I have been busy on
the "thinking5* side the last few weeks and now comes January, a month of action.
The schedule looks something like this:
January engineering group meeting in Chicago to discuss tape
making, tape duplicating, and tape playing standards. The group will meet with
representatives of Minnesota Mining, Magnecorder, and possibly others. And then
we'll move that night to tlrbana to look over the set-up here and make the specific
recomasrd&tlons mentioned above.
I will stay in Chicago January h for a meeting with Siegel, Harley, and
Prohst, on promotion plans for the coming Ford programs.
The night of the 4th, all of us move to Ames, Iowa, for a meeting of the
Committee of Five, which will hear some tapes of Ford shows and view some Lines
of the shows WOI is producing under the Ford grant.
January 7—finds us in St. Louis for the Mayor's Conference on TV.
January 8—1 plan to visit Marguerite Fleming's installation in the
St. Louis Public Schools.
Then comes a week of planning, followed by the Planning Group Committee
meeting in Lafayette on January 17, 18, and 19.
Shortly thereafter I expect to leave for Washington for some visits with
peoples there and to attend the annual meeting of the American Council on Education.
A hurried return from. Washington to Urbana for a series of meetings here
around the first of February. Plans are not complete on these as yet so will have
to give you the details later.
They are progressing well here at Illinois j reports I get from Wisconsin,
Cleveland, Columbus, Ames, Washington, and New York indicate that everybody is
well and busy.
I trust the next report will have more meat in it.
Jim Miles
